author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Bets on Rate Cuts This Year Are Fading Away
description: Stubborn inflation has led traders to forecast far fewer rate cuts by the Federal Reserve than just a few months ago.
content: At the start of 2024, investors expected the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates substantially this year as inflation cooled. But price increases have been surprisingly stubborn, and that is forcing a rethink on Wall Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Taunts Trump, Calling Him a ‘Loser,’ Trying to Get Under His Skin
description: President Biden has been trying to hit his opponent where it hurts, critiquing everything from his hairstyle to his energy levels in court.
content: This week, one presidential candidate has called the other a loser, made fun of him for selling Bibles, and even poked fun at his hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Friday Briefing
description: The Supreme Court considers presidential immunity.
content: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority appeared ready yesterday to rule that former presidents have some degree of immunity from criminal prosecution, which could further delay the criminal case against Donald Trump on charges that he plotted to subvert the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Number of Trump Allies Facing Election Interference Charges Keeps Growing
description: Prosecutors are sending a warning as Donald Trump and his supporters continue to spread conspiracy theories: that disrupting elections can bear a heavy legal cost.
content: Fifty-three people who tried to keep former President Donald J. Trump in power after he lost the 2020 election have now been criminally charged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein and Krista Schlueter
title: At the Time 100 Gala, Glamour Meets Influence
description: Dua Lipa and Patrick Mahomes are red carpet stars at an event that brought together Oscar winners and thought leaders.
content: “This line is crazy,” said the broadcast journalist Don Lemon, as he walked toward the red carpet crush shortly after 7 p.m. on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Taylor Swift Needs to Become Other People
description: If commerce demands constant songwriting, she needs new characters to play.
content: The biggest cultural news of the month is that a lot of people are kind of “meh” about Taylor Swift’s latest album (or albums, if you prefer to treat the 31-song release as a twofer). After spending the past few years illustrating how internet-era culture encourages a singular kind of superstardom, to the point where Swift has sometimes felt like the only celebrity singer in the world — or maybe that’s just how it feels when you’re driving a minivan with tween-age daughters making song requests — we’ve maybe, maybe finally hit a point of overextension and oversaturation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Noah Weiland
title: Biden Delays Ban on Menthol Cigarettes
description: The proposal had been years in the making, in an effort to curb death rates of Black smokers targeted by Big Tobacco. In an election year, the president’s worries about support among Black voters may have influenced the postponement.
content: The Biden administration said on Friday that it was delaying a decision on whether to ban menthol cigarettes, effectively quashing a proposal that has divided Black American voters and fueled million-dollar lobbying campaigns from the tobacco industry in this presidential election year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: An Enduring Race Tax
description: Black Americans remain the only racial group with a homeownership rate below 50 percent.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: One for the Record Books
description: David Leonhardt and his wife, Laura, take on a puzzle by Matthew Stock and Christina Iverson.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: On Stand, Pecker Fires Back After Trump Lawyer Implies He Was Untruthful
description: The confrontational strategy adopted by the lawyer, Emil Bove, did not seem to work with David Pecker, the former publisher of The National Enquirer.
content: The lawyer for Donald J. Trump who on Friday led the cross-examination of David Pecker, the former publisher of The National Enquirer and first witness in the trial, used confrontational questioning to try to catch Mr. Pecker in contradictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Do You Like About Playing Games?
description: What games do you love? Which ones do you like playing alone, and which do you prefer to play with others? What do you get from gaming?
content: Teachers, we also have a related lesson plan about teaching with seven New York Times games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Mike Faist and Josh O’Connor Spar Over Churros in ‘Challengers’
description: The director Luca Guadagnino narrates a tense scene between the two characters.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Uncle Impermanence
description: Should a divorce get them removed from the family tree?
content: Josh writes: My wife, Karla, claims that the title of aunt or uncle can be revoked. I think that once the niece or nephew is born, the title stays — regardless of divorce, remarriage or death. There are two exceptions: If the title is honorary, or if there is separation before children. But once there are children, an aunt or uncle cannot be removed from the family tree. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aziz Rana
title: The Constitution Won’t Save Us From Trump
description: Turning the page on the man — and on the politics he has fostered — will require fundamentally changing the text of our founding document.
content: On Thursday, the Supreme Court gathered to consider whether Donald Trump, as president, enjoyed immunity from prosecution for attempting to overturn the 2020 election. Even if the justices eventually rule against him, liberals should not celebrate the Constitution as our best bulwark against Mr. Trump. In fact, the document — for reasons that go beyond Mr. Trump, that long preceded him and could well extend past him — has made our democracy almost unworkable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Janofsky
title: Exploring Atomic Bomb History Beyond Los Alamos
description: The Atomic Museum in Las Vegas explains to visitors that Nevada and other states also played a role — for better or worse — in the creation of nuclear energy.
content: The blockbuster movie about J. Robert Oppenheimer might have left the impression that only New Mexico was involved in developing America’s atomic bomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann, Sandra E. Garcia and Frank Rojas
title: Denied a Second Chance at a Normal Senior Year
description: After Covid ruined high school graduation for the class of 2020, the response to campus protests might upend their college commencements.
content: Divya Jakatdar imagined that she would spend her senior year of high school celebrating college acceptances with her friends, attending prom and walking across the stage at graduation to the cheers of her family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: TikTok on the Clock, Tesla’s Flop Era and How NASA Fixed a ’70s-Era Space Computer
description: “A clock is ticking on one of America’s most famous apps.”
content: On Wednesday, President Biden signed a bill into law that would force the sale of TikTok or ban the app outright. We explain how this came together, when just a few weeks ago it seemed unlikely to happen, and what legal challenges the law will face next. Then we check on Tesla’s very bad year and what’s next for the company after this week’s awful quarterly earnings report. Finally, to boldly support tech where tech has never been supported before: Engineers at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Lab try to fix a chip malfunction from 15 billion miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Trump’s trial is the latest chapter in the rich history of Lower Manhattan’s courts.
description: A cluster of downtown buildings has served as the borough’s “epicenter of criminal justice in New York since the 1830s,” said a lawyer who has led walking tours of Manhattan courthouses.
content: For a decade, Robert Pigott, a lawyer, has led walking tours of the courthouses of Manhattan, guiding visitors around landmarks where the city’s rich legal history has played out. Now the trial of Donald J. Trump has added a chapter to the story he gets to tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Lescaze
title: Ancient Female Ballplayer Makes Public Debut
description: The statue will be part of “Ancient Huasteca Women: Goddesses, Warriors and Governors” at the National Museum of Mexican Art in Chicago.
content: The woman, carved in pale stone, wears a peaked headdress, circular earrings and the wide hip belt and kneepads of an ancient Mesoamerican athlete. Her expression is fierce, her pose triumphant. In her right hand, she grips the severed head of a sacrificial victim by the hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: PEN America Cancels World Voices Festival Amid Israel-Gaza Criticism
description: The decision by the free expression group came after intense criticism of its response to the war in Gaza. A wave of participants had pulled out of the festival in protest.
content: The free expression organization PEN America has canceled its annual World Voices Festival after a wave of participants withdrew, spurred by a boycott campaign led by writers who say the group’s response to the war in Gaza has been insufficiently critical of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: Americans Went All-In on Self-Storage. That Demand Is Suddenly Cooling.
description: Many developers, spurred by the pandemic to invest money in new self-storage facilities, have been caught short by this drop in demand.
content: Peter Chu, a retired lawyer living in Portland, Ore., pays nearly $400 a month for his storage unit in Seattle, where he used to live. That rate has gone up by roughly $150 since 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Did Richard III Kill the Princes in the Tower?
description: Philippa Langley devoted years to the search for Richard III’s remains. Now, she’s trying to crack a 15th-century cold case: Did he really assassinate his nephews?
content: For over 400 years, Richard III has been seen as Britain’s most infamous king — a power-hungry usurper who killed his young nephews to clear the way to the throne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: At Least Three Women Were Infected With H.I.V. After ‘Vampire Facials’
description: The women underwent the cosmetic procedure at an unlicensed spa in New Mexico.
content: At least three women were infected with H.I.V. during cosmetic “vampire facial” procedures at an unlicensed spa in Albuquerque, federal officials said Thursday. It is the first time that H.I.V. transmission through cosmetic injection services has been documented, they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooklyn White-Grier
title: Rebuilding After a Fire. Are Things Really Just Things?
description: A writer reflects on what it means to lose nearly everything in a disaster, as she moves into a new home.
content: It was a day like any other — the day my home was engulfed by fire. No one on earth or above asked me if I was ready for the shoulder shake. The morning started with a buzzy, two-minute car ride to my daughter’s school. It ended with us — me, my husband, our then 4-year old and 1-year-old — sharing a queen-size bed at my in-law’s house. I spent the night gasping for air while on my husband’s phone with my friends and family. My phone had been lost to the blaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vinnie Neuberg
title: Putting the Spotlight on Spot Illustrations
description: Small sketches that appear on the top of Page A3 of the newspaper provide a daily dose of delight.
content: As the art director of the Inside the Times section, one of my duties every month is hiring an artist to draw a series of small illustrations that appear daily on the top of Page A3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Auto Safety Regulator Investigating Tesla Recall of Autopilot
description: The National Highway Safety Administration also released an analysis of crashes involving the system that showed at least 29 fatal accidents over five and a half years.
content: The federal government’s main auto safety agency said on Friday that it was investigating Tesla’s recall of its Autopilot driver-assistance system because regulators were concerned that the company had not done enough to ensure that drivers remained attentive while using the technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Mickalene Thomas Takes Los Angeles
description: The Broad Museum kicks off a touring exhibition of the artist’s work over the last 20 years.
content: Mickalene Thomas has been getting into neon. But then, the artist is constantly exploring new materials and methods, which is why her practice includes painting, collage, sculpture, printmaking, photography and video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Schumer Says Foreign Aid Victory Shows Congress Isn’t Broken
description: The majority leader says the measure to help Ukraine and other recent bipartisan efforts show there is a path to success on Capitol Hill. But deep partisan differences and institutional problems remain.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, the New York Democrat and majority leader, insists that Congress isn’t broken — it just has a stubborn glitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: This Whole King Trump Thing Is Getting Awfully Literal
description: The former president’s claim that he has absolute immunity for criminal acts taken in office as president is an insult to reason.
content: Donald Trump’s claim that he has absolute immunity for criminal acts taken in office as president is an insult to reason, an assault on common sense and a perversion of the fundamental maxim of American democracy: that no man is above the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Beth Linker Is Turning Good Posture on Its Head
description: A historian and sociologist of science re-examines the “posture panic” of the last century. You’ll want to sit down for this.
content: For decades, the idea of standing properly upright carried considerable political and social baggage. Slouching was considered a sign of decay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: King Charles to Return to Public Duties, Reassuring Anxious Royal Watchers
description: The king’s cancer treatment will continue but doctors are “pleased with the progress made so far,” a palace spokesman said.
content: King Charles III will return to public duties next week, Buckingham Palace announced on Friday, an encouraging sign of his recovery, nearly three months after he disclosed that he had cancer, and a palpable relief to a country anxious about another wrenching change in the British monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Winnie Hu
title: Congestion Pricing Will Start on June 30 in New York City, M.T.A. Says
description: Transit officials announced the start of the program, which they have said will ease some of the nation’s worst traffic.
content: The first comprehensive congestion-pricing program in a major U.S. city will begin in New York on June 30, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow and Jillian Weinberger
title: Biden, Let the Protests of 1968 Be a Warning
description: Lessons from a tumultuous summer.
content: In 1968, protests against the Vietnam War reached a climax in Chicago outside the Democratic National Convention, where the police beat and arrested demonstrators — and most likely contributed to Hubert Humphrey’s loss in the general election that November. In this audio essay, the columnist Charles Blow draws a parallel between those events and this year’s convention, which will also take place in Chicago and where protesters are again planning demonstrations. Blow warns the Biden campaign that the growing campus protest movement signals what could come and that the campaign ignores history at its peril.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron Report Lower Earnings
description: Profits for the two oil giants, which are locked in a standoff over drilling off the coast of Guyana, were squeezed by lower profitability for refining crude and falling natural gas prices.
content: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the largest American energy companies, said on Friday that their earnings in the first quarter fell from a year earlier, pulled down by lower margins on oil refining and plunging natural gas prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Cecil Williams, Whose San Francisco Church Became a Haven, Dies at 94
description: As the well-connected pastor of the Glide Memorial Church in the blighted Tenderloin district, he preached a “radically inclusive” gospel in serving people in need.
content: The Rev. Cecil Williams, a charismatic minister who turned a fading church in the gritty Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco into a vibrant hub of worship, activism and social services, died on Monday at his home in the city. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Andrés Eulogizes 7 Aid Workers Killes in Gaza as ‘the Best of Humanity’
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 26, 2024.
content: “They risked everything to feed people they did not know and will never meet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Popescu
title: Can the Best Fossils Ever Found Answer the Biggest Dinosaur Question?
description: Two creatures unearthed in 2006, and finally on display in North Carolina, might hold the key to a major debate over a certain animal’s identity.
content: If you’ve ever wanted to see, touch or even smell what life was like when the dinosaurs walked the earth, this is the place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Police Arrest Rabbis Near Gaza-Israel Border at a Rally to Highlight Starvation
description: A group of about 30 rabbis and peace activists from Israel and the United States was trying to take food supplies into the territory.
content: Seven rabbis and peace activists were arrested on Friday near the border with Gaza after they tried to take food supplies into the territory, according to two participants and the campaign group that organized the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Pentagon Announces Additional $6 Billion in Military Aid for Ukraine
description: The funds will allow Kyiv to purchase weapons directly from American defense companies.
content: The United States will give Ukraine $6 billion to purchase military hardware directly from American defense companies, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III announced on Friday, expressing confidence that many of the weapons and munitions the country most needs will soon arrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Jury Deadlocks on Murder Count Against Ex-Deputy in Killing of Colorado Man
description: A jury convicted the former deputy of reckless endangerment in the fatal shooting of a man who called 911 for help, but said it was unable to reach a verdict on charges of murder and official misconduct.
content: A former sheriff’s deputy who fatally shot a 22-year-old man who had called 911 for help in June 2022 was found guilty on Friday of reckless endangerment, though a Colorado jury said it was unable to reach a verdict on charges of murder and official misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Paramount Chief Executive Bob Bakish Could Be Out Next Week
description: He was once a staunch ally of the company’s biggest owner, Shari Redstone, but the relationship soured in recent months.
content: Paramount is preparing to announce the departure of its chief executive, Bob Bakish, as soon as next week, according to three people with knowledge of the matter, a sudden development even as the company is exploring a merger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day and Lauren Herstik
title: Britney Spears and Her Father Settle Legal Dispute Over Conservatorship
description: Terms were not disclosed. The parties had been arguing over the payment of legal fees and James P. Spears’s financial oversight as his daughter’s conservator.
content: More than two years after a judge ended the conservatorship that had given James P. Spears control of his pop star daughter’s life, Britney Spears and her father have settled their outstanding legal dispute over the payment of his legal fees and his management of her finances.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taylor Swift: The ‘Tortured’ Mailbag
description: Answering your questions about the sound and substance of the pop superstar’s double album, and the way fans and critics have responded to it.
content: “The Tortured Poets Department,” the new album from Taylor Swift, will have the biggest opening week of any album this year. Critical reaction to the release has been mixed, but fan interest has remained extremely high. And questions about Swift’s music and motivations abound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: St. Vincent’s 10 (or, Actually 11) Essential Songs
description: Sample her seven daring and eclectic albums as her latest, “All Born Screaming,” arrives.
content: One afternoon in late February, my editor Caryn asked if I might be interested in profiling St. Vincent ahead of her new album “All Born Screaming.” I said that I probably wasn’t — though I have long been a fan, my early spring schedule was quite full and the reporting would require a short-notice trip to Los Angeles — but that I would give the album a spin on the way home from work, just to see if it would change my mind. By the fourth track, I was searching flights to L.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Justices
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: A New ‘Great Gatsby’ Leads With Comedy and Romance
description: This musical adaptation, now on Broadway, is a lot of Jazz Age fun. But it forgot that Fitzgerald’s 1925 novel endures because it is a tragedy.
content: Jay Gatsby — self-made enigma, party host extraordinaire and talk of the summer season in West Egg, Long Island — doesn’t carry his insecurities lightly. The facade of his wealth-drenched life is a grand and precarious creation, and propping it up requires constant vigilance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: interloper
description: This word has appeared in 33 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word interloper has appeared in 33 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 26 in “Will Country Welcome Beyoncé? That’s the Wrong Question” by Jon Caramanica:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: When U.S. Diplomats Visit China, Meal Choices Are About More Than Taste Buds
description: Visits to China by American officials like Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken can bring fame to local restaurants, as well as scrutiny to the dignitaries.
content: Beijing beer made with American hops, to highlight the trade relationship between the two countries. Tibetan food, to send a human rights message. Mushrooms with possible hallucinogenic properties, just because they taste good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Peter Meijer, Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Withdraws From G.O.P. Senate Primary
description: Mr. Meijer, a former House member, said he did not have a “strong pathway to victory” in the Michigan primary race.
content: Peter Meijer, a Republican who voted to impeach former President Donald J. Trump when he was a member of the House, announced on Friday that he was dropping out of the Republican primary race for U.S. Senate in Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Baskets Holding the Identity of an Indigenous People
description: The baskets of Jeremy Frey from the Passamaquoddy tribe in Maine have caught the attention of the art world.
content: Long before painters such as Winslow Homer and Andrew Wyeth arrived in Maine to capture its spectacular natural beauty on canvas, the native Wabanaki people used materials from the landscape to weave black ash and sweet grass baskets, the oldest continuously practiced art form in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Israel Has a Choice to Make: Rafah or Riyadh
description: Israel is facing one of the most fateful choices it has ever had to make.
content: U.S. diplomacy to end the Gaza war and forge a new relationship with Saudi Arabia has been converging in recent weeks into a single giant choice for Israel and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: What do you want more — Rafah or Riyadh?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine Is Denying Consular Services to Men Outside the Country
description: New guidance carries a clear message to men abroad who may be avoiding the draft: You don’t get the benefit of state services if you don’t join the fight.
content: Ukrainian officials have taken several steps in recent weeks to swell the ranks of an army depleted by more than two years of grueling combat. The government passed a new mobilization bill aimed at increasing troop numbers and has stepped up border patrols to catch draft dodgers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Yoo
title: Asian American Children Are Front and Center in a New Version of a Groundbreaking Work
description: Erika Lee and Christina Soontornvat’s “Made in Asian America” spotlights young people who defy erasure and make their own history.
content: I had never seen an Asian person in a book until my first-grade teacher read “The Five Chinese Brothers,” by Claire Huchet Bishop and Kurt Wiese, to our class. At recess, the other children stretched the corners of their eyes, imitating the illustrations. In high school, my social studies textbooks relegated the Chinese laborers who risked their lives to build the transcontinental railroad, and the 120,000 Japanese Americans illegally incarcerated during World War II, to impactless sidebars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Watchdog Group Accuses Trump Campaign of Violating Finance Law
description: The Campaign Legal Center said in a complaint that Trump political committees had used an intermediary firm “as a conduit to conceal payments” totaling $7.2 million.
content: A campaign watchdog group filed a formal complaint to the Federal Election Commission on Wednesday accusing Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign and related political committees of concealing payments of $7.2 million in legal fees by paying them through an unrelated shell company in violation of campaign finance law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: A Portrait of a Saint Is Reincarnated in Milwaukee
description: The painting “Saint Francis of Assisi in His Tomb” became one of the inspirations for Idris Khan in his first solo museum show in the United States.
content: For nearly 66 years, the centuries-old painting of a shadowy, cloaked figure holding a skull, his face unseen, on a canvas almost seven feet tall, has hung prominently at the Milwaukee Art Museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 320
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: When the V.I.P. Wedding Guests are Mandy Moore and a Hissing Goose
description: Evan Ross Katz, a writer and podcaster, and Billy Jacobson, an engineer, exchanged vows on 4/20, complete with a weed-infused reception, pop culture references and fashionable guests.
content: In June 2018, Billy Jacobson met a guy on the dating app Grindr whom he recognized from the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Decaille
title: Their Sunday Ritual Kept Them Connected
description: Asiah James and Gerald Cannon II initially went with the flow, but after years of balancing professional ambitions and quality time together, decided to join forces forever.
content: Asiah Janai James was feeling spontaneous in August 2014 when she invited her co-worker, Gerald Leon Cannon II, to meet up with her at the Afropunk Festival in the Fort Greene neighborhood of Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘The Royal Hotel,’ ‘Zola’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Female-centered buddy comedies, rom-coms and Outback thrillers are among the under-the-radar recommendations for your subscription streamers this month.
content: Kitty Green’s follow-up to the taut drama “The Assistant” is a feminist riff on the ’70s classic “Wake in Fright,” in which two Canadian tourists who have run out of money in Australia take on a gig as bartenders at a grimy watering hole in the middle of nowhere. “It’s a large mining area,” they’re told, so “you’re going to have to be OK with a little male attention.” For 90 tightly-wound minutes, Green mixes bleary naturalism and baked-in dread, as these modern women are exposed to the handsy, winking Neanderthal clientele, and the bar turns into a ticking time bomb. Julia Garner and Jessica Henwick are empathetic in the leads, while Daniel Henshall is all quiet menace as the establishment’s most boorish regular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: After Apartheid
description: Thirty years after apartheid ended, South Africa will vote again.
content: South Africa’s apartheid government died in an election 30 years ago tomorrow. For the first time, Black South Africans were among those casting ballots. In the regime’s place, voters inaugurated a democracy led by people who look like the country’s majority. Hopes ran high: Nelson Mandela became president and vowed to help Black communities prosper by giving them access to the wealth, land and mines — South Africa is rich in gold and diamonds — colonizers had taken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Warren Buffett’s Real Estate Brokerage Agrees to $250 Million Settlement
description: HomeServices of America, the largest residential real estate brokerage in the United States, will settle the claims brought by home sellers who said they were forced to pay inflated commissions, pending court approval.
content: HomeServices of America, the largest residential real estate brokerage in the United States and owned by Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Energy, has agreed to settle a series of lawsuits that could change the way commissions are paid to real estate agents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Jonathan Swan
title: Biden, Asked if He’s Planning to Debate Trump, Says ‘I Am’
description: The president’s announcement came after months in which he and his campaign declined to say whether he would debate his predecessor.
content: President Biden said on Friday that he would participate in a general-election debate with former President Donald J. Trump, a striking shift after months in which he and his campaign declined to commit to appearing onstage with his Republican rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Mostly Persuasive Logic Behind the New Ban on Noncompetes
description: The F.T.C. argued that noncompetes don’t just harm workers. They also harm society.

content: The workplace in “Jordans,” an ambitious but unwieldy new play at the Public Theater, is so white that it’s a bit alarming. I don’t mean to say it’s full of white people (though it certainly is that, too), but rather that the aesthetic of the space itself catches your attention: minimalist, modern, white screens and walls. By the end of the play, however, those bright white spaces will be covered with blood.

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Uncropped’: Images That Make You Want to Pause the Movie
description: A documentary celebrates the work of the revered photographer James Hamilton.
content: A photograph is a record of the past from the moment the shutter snaps, which lends the medium a bit of wistfulness. That emotion also permeates “Uncropped” (in theaters), D.W. Young’s documentary about the eminent photographer James Hamilton. It’s not a biographical movie, at least not in the usual sense, though Young keeps the filmmaking stripped-down and simple. For the most part, “Uncropped” involves conversations between Hamilton and various friends, mostly around tables in his apartment and others’. Journalists, photographers and the odd celebrity or two (Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth, the director Wes Anderson) discuss Hamilton’s work and recount the old days. Interspersed with the conversations are shots of Hamilton’s photos, often breathtaking images that make you want to pause the movie and just look.

But that’s the message I heard loud and clear 17 years ago, in my first job after completing my Ph.D. in evolutionary biology. content: The Joan Didion many people know is constructed from a few artifacts the real writer left behind when she died in 2021. There’s her much-imitated (and sometimes parodied) 1967 essay “Goodbye to All That,” about leaving New York. There’s the packing list enumerated in her essay “The White Album,” written between 1968 and 1978, which is sometimes cited as aspirational, even instructional. There are the iconic photographs of Didion taken by Julian Wasser in 1968, commissioned for a profile in Time — particularly one in which she’s smoking while leaning against her Stingray, cooler than anyone has ever been, a vibe echoed in the 2003 ad Didion shot for the fashion brand Celine. And, of course, there’s her most famous line — “We tell ourselves stories in order to live” — which opens “The White Album” and is frequently invoked, wrongly, for inspiration.

content: In the 16th century, Antwerp, Belgium, with its busy docks along the river Scheldt, was a booming center of trade and one of Europe’s most influential cities, attracting artists, intellectuals and entrepreneurs. In 1576, Christophe Plantin ran a prestigious printing business (one of the continent’s largest) in the center of the city, a half-mile from where, a few decades later, the painter Peter Paul Rubens would build his own studio and semicircular sculpture hall, modeled after the Pantheon. Over the years, while other long-established port cities like Venice and Barcelona evolved into throbbing tourist centers, Belgium’s second city largely kept far away from the spotlight, yet it’s always quietly maintained a reputation as a place for innovation and creative expression. In the 1980s, it became an important fashion hub with the emergence of the Antwerp Six: a group of young designers, including Ann Demeulemeester, who had been educated at the city’s Royal Academy of Fine Arts.

title: N.F.L. Draft Had Some Style Winners
description: The next class of football stars has done some fashion homework, but the evening was pretty tame compared with the N.B.A. draft.
content: “People want to sit around with the family and watch football,” Roger Goodell, the National Football League commissioner, said Thursday night before the 2024 N.F.L. draft. It is also increasingly the case that people want to sit around, alone or in groups, watching phenomenal athletes and physical specimens doing nothing more physically taxing than sauntering down a red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘Good Material,’ by Dolly Alderton
description: The writer Dolly Alderton has long had an avid following in her native England, but with her best-selling comic novel “Good Material” she’s become a trans-Atlantic success.
content: How to explain the British writer Dolly Alderton to an American audience? It might be best to let her work speak for itself — it certainly does! — but Alderton is such a cultural phenomenon in her native England that some context is probably helpful: “Like Nora Ephron, With a British Twist” is the way we put it when we reviewed her latest novel, “Good Material,” earlier this year.

title: How Does Trump’s Violent Rhetoric End?

content: How worried should we really be about the threat of political violence? On this week’s episode of “Matter of Opinion,” columnist Jamelle Bouie joins the hosts to set the record straight on whether we’re actually living through an unusually violent era, and they discuss whether the new movie, “Civil War,” could come true.

content: More than 7,000 workers who make trucks and buses at Daimler Truck plants in North Carolina are poised to go on strike at midnight, barring a last-minute breakthrough. content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will visit Israel next week, an Israeli official said on Friday, as talks on a cease-fire deal have stalled and tensions have risen between Israel and the United States over the treatment of civilians in the war.

title: Federal Officials Find No Live Bird Flu Virus in Initial Milk Tests
description: The early results suggest that pasteurization is killing the H5N1 virus in milk, something that regulators were not certain of.
content: Federal regulators on Friday said that they had not yet discovered live bird flu virus in the first batch of retail milk samples they tested, a reassuring indication that the milk on store shelves remains safe despite an outbreak of the virus among dairy cows.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Conservative Justices Take Argument Over Trump’s Immunity in Unexpected Direction

content: Before the Supreme Court heard arguments on Thursday on former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from prosecution, his stance was widely seen as a brazen and cynical bid to delay his trial. The practical question in the case, it was thought, was not whether the court would rule against him but whether it would act quickly enough to allow the trial to go forward before the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Putting Sexual Assault on Trial, in a Fraught One-Woman Case
description: The actress Jodie Comer recasts her Tony-winning turn in Suzie Miller’s hit play “Prima Facie” for a new novelization.
content: For Tessa Ensler, a young hotshot barrister on the rise in London’s criminal courts, the law is a game to be relished. In defending the accused, she sees her role as merely telling the better story: the one that the jury believes. As for the truth of her clients’ claims of innocence, she has been trained not to inquire.

title: Corrections: April 26, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 26, 2026.
content: Pamela Paul’s column on April 5 described incorrectly Romona Harden’s time in college. After the pandemic shut down in-person classes, she went home and completed her degree remotely. She did not drop out of college.

title: ‘Where’s Cricket?’ Don’t Ask. Kristi Noem Defends Killing Her Dog.

title: How to Show Up for a Friend Getting Divorced
description: The end of a marriage can be incredibly isolating. But small gestures from loved ones can provide some relief.
content: When my sister Dinah’s marriage ended after 25 years, one of her friends set up twice weekly “vent walks,” where my sister could say anything she wanted about her divorce — with no fear she was being a burden.

content: On Wednesday, President Biden signed into law a bill that would force TikTok’s Chinese owners to sell the app or face a ban in the United States. Though the government prefers a sale to a ban, a future without the app would be possible if no sale is made within 270 days, or about nine months, a time frame that the president could extend to a year.

title: Paramedic Avoids Prison in Death of Elijah McClain
description: The sentencing marked the final chapter of a case that stretched over nearly five years and helped usher in sweeping public safety reforms.
content: A Colorado paramedic convicted in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young, unarmed Black man, was sentenced to four years of probation with 14 months of work release on Friday, the final chapter of an explosive case that thrust the Denver suburb of Aurora into the national spotlight and helped usher in sweeping public safety reforms.

content: With the Caribbean Sea as its backdrop, this three-bedroom, two-bath home from 2005 is in Seafeathers, a residential enclave on Anguilla’s eastern coast. The home enjoys views across the water as far as St. Maarten and St. Bart’s. Sandy Hill Beach, popular with snorkelers, is about two miles west of the villa. The Valley, Anguilla’s capital and business hub, is about five miles west.
